speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks for being here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, my colleagues and I decided to leave our policy rate unchanged.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As always, we base our decisions on our judgment of how best to achieve the goals Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe monetary policy is well positioned to serve the American people by supporting continued economic growth, a strong job market, and a return of inflation to our symmetric 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The expansion is in its 11th year, the longest on record.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth in household spending moderated toward the end of last year, but with a healthy job market, rising incomes, and upbeat consumer confidence, the fundamentals supporting household spending are solid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, business investment and exports remain weak, and manufacturing output has declined over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sluggish growth abroad and trade developments have been weighing on activity in these sectors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, some of the uncertainties around trade have diminished recently, and there are some signs that global growth may be stabilizing after declining since mid-2018.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, uncertainties about the outlook remain, including those posed by the new coronavirus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, with monetary and financial conditions supportive, we expect moderate economic growth to continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate has been near half-century lows for well more than a year, and the pace of job gains remains solid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participation in the labor force by people in their prime working years, ages 25 to 54, is at its highest level in more than a decade.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And wages have been rising, particularly for lower-paying jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People who live and work in middle-income communities and low-income communities tell us that many who have struggled to find work are now finding new opportunities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Employment gains have been broad based across all racial and ethnic groups and all levels of education.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These developments underscore for us the importance of sustaining the expansion so that the strong job market reaches more of those left behind.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation continues to run below our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months through November, total PCE inflation was 1.5 percent, and core inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, was 1.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Available data suggest similar inflation readings for December, though we expect inflation to move closer to 2 percent over the next few months as unusually low readings from early 2019 drop out of the calculation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While low and stable inflation is certainly a good thing, inflation that runs persistently below our objective can lead longer-term inflation expectations to drift down, pulling actual inflation even lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In turn, interest rates would be lower as well—closer to their effective lower bound.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a result, we would have less room to reduce interest rates to support the economy in a future downturn to the detriment of American families and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have seen this dynamic play out in other economies around the world, and we are determined to avoid it here in the United States.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, we believe the current stance of monetary policy is appropriate to support sustained economic growth, a strong labor market, and inflation returning to our 2 percent—symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As long as incoming information about the economy remains broadly consistent with this outlook, the current stance of monetary policy likely will remain appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will be monitoring the effects of the policy actions we took last year, along with other information bearing on the outlook, as we assess the appropriate path of the target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, if developments emerge that cause a material reassessment of our outlook, we would respond accordingly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Policy is not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will conclude with a brief overview of our current plans for our technical operations to implement monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The plan the FOMC announced back in October to purchase Treasury bills and conduct repo operations has proceeded smoothly and has succeeded in providing an ample supply of reserves to the banking system and effectively controlling the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of the resulting stability in the federal funds rate and money market conditions more generally, we decided to make a small technical upward adjustment to administered rates to ensure that the federal funds rate trades well within the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This action reverses the small downward adjustment made in September when money markets were volatile.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As our bill purchases continue to build reserves toward levels that maintain ample conditions, the role played by active repo operations will naturally recede.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the first half of this year, we intend to adjust the size and pricing of repo operations as we transition away from their active use in supplying reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This process will take place gradually, and, as indicated in today’s FOMC directive to the Desk, we expect to continue offering repos at least through April to ensure a consistently ample supply of reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Based on current projections, we expect that the underlying level of reserves will durably reach ample levels sometime in the second quarter of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we get close to that point, we intend to slow the pace of purchases and transition to a program of smaller reserve management purchases that maintains an ample level of reserves without the active use of repos.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At that point, as in the pre-crisis period, our balance sheet will be expanding gradually over time, reflecting the trend growth in the demand for currency and other Federal Reserve liabilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of these technical measures are designed to support the efficient and effective implementation of monetary policy and are not intended to represent a chance—a change in the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to completing the transition to our longer-run ample-reserves regime smoothly and predictably.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we will continue to closely monitor conditions in money markets, and we will adjust these plans as conditions warrant.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I’ll be happy to take your questions.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Chris Condon, Bloomberg News.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Mr. Chairman, I would like you to comment in a little bit more depth about one small change I’ve noted in the statement.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: It notes that policy will be appropriate to bring—the Committee believes—inflation back to the Committee’s 2 percent symmetric inflation objective.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: That’s a slight change from the last time, when you were expecting it to bring inflation outcomes back near the objective.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: And I would put this also in the context of a comment you made at the last press conference where you drew attention to the fact that a number of policymakers had projected inflation overshoots two or three years out under appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Should we take all of this together to mean simply that the Committee is more confident that a 2 percent outcome for inflation is already baked in the cake, or that this is a signal that the Committee has a stronger resolution to bring inflation at least to the 2 percent objective and put—bring into play an informal makeup strategy for inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in making that change, our goal was, really—that was, changing “near” to “returning to”—was to avoid possible misinterpretation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you may remember, in the December minutes we noted that a few Committee members suggested that the language that stated that monetary policy would support inflation near 2 percent could be misinterpreted as suggesting that policymakers were comfortable with inflation running below that level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we thought about that in the intermeeting period and concluded that it would be appropriate to adjust that language to send a clearer signal that we’re not comfortable with inflation rising persistently—running persistently below our 2 percent symmetric objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, yes, there is something in that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just that we wanted to underscore our commitment to 2 percent not being a ceiling to inflation running around—symmetrically around 2 percent, and that we’re not satisfied with inflation running below 2 percent, particularly at a time such as now where we’re a long way into an expansion and a long way into a period of very low unemployment when, in theory, inflation should be moving up.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: I want to ask about the balance sheet.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: How many reserves are “ample”?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: How many reserves does the Fed now think it will need to conduct policy in its current framework?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And can you walk me through how you and your colleagues are arriving at that answer?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, thanks for that question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Why don’t I say a few things about repos, since I know that’ll be of interest.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, just to bring you back, after last September’s brief turmoil, we took prompt and decisive action, and a result—as a result, money markets have been operating smoothly since then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just to review, those two adjustments were Treasury bill purchases of at least—of $60 billion—sorry—at least into the second quarter, and term and overnight repo at least through April.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I will get to your specific question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The purpose of the adjustments has been to assure that our policy is transmitted smoothly to the federal funds rate, which requires well-functioning money markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t mean we’re trying to eliminate all volatility in the repo markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that some volatility is normal and expected in well-functioning markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, these adjustments have been successful in supplying an ample quantity of reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Money markets operated smoothly, including right through year-end, and the fed funds rate has remained in our target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we know—we will know when these adjustments have run their course when reserves are durably at a level that enables us to control the federal funds rate using our administered rates, the interest on reserves and reverse repo, without the need for frequent use of open market operations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Based on current projections, we expect that the bill purchases will durably bring the underlying level of reserves to the ample level sometime in the second quarter of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when we see that we’ve reached that level, we’ll begin to gradually reduce our asset purchases to the level of the underlying trend growth of demand for our liabilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As our bill purchases bring the underlying level of reserves up to an ample level on a sustained basis, the necessary quantity of overnight and term repo will gradually decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve already begun the gradual reduction in the quantity of repo, and we’ll continue to reduce those offering amounts gradually as conditions permit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At some point, we’ll also raise the minimum bid rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even after we reach an ample level of reserves, it’s possible that repo operations might play a role as a backstop and support effective control of the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll continue to discuss that issue and review it under our implementation framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Coming to your question, in terms of the actually desired reserve level, we know that reserves will continue to move up and down over the course of the calendar year in a wide range depending on volatility in nonreserve liabilities, particularly the Treasury General Account, or TGA.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, reserve levels will need to be at a level high enough to remain ample even when the TGA peaks during the April tax season.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Effectively, what that means is that we need reserves at all times to be no lower than they were in early September—and, I would say, around $1½ trillion, subject to learning more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reserves are going to move in a broad range, as I mentioned, and we want to be clear, that will be the bottom end of the range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want $1½ trillion or thereabouts to be the bottom end of the range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, most of the time, reserves will be moving in a range substantially higher than that but not going below $1½ trillion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s not an—it’s not something that we’re aiming at all the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know that reserves will fluctuate and be substantially higher than that most of the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also want interest on excess reserves and the fed funds rate to be well within the FOMC’s target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that’ll be the case now that we made our technical adjustment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Last points—we’re committed to making this adjustment process a smooth one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll provide more details as we go, and we expect to learn as we go, as we always have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re prepared to adjust the details of the plan as necessary to foster efficient and effective monetary policy implementation.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, thank you for the question.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Following up on Nick’s question, I know you said it’s not QE, but it’s $390 billion over five months, which is a lot to expand the balance sheet.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I guess I’d ask one more time on Nick’s question—is there a number that you have in mind?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Secondly, a lot of people in the market are sort of concerned that it looks like QE, and they’re trading that way.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Are you concerned that the market is embracing this like a QE program, and that the rise in the stock market is linked to it, and you may then experience something of a “taper tantrum” the way Chairman Bernanke did when he tried to roll it off?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ll just—I’ll repeat that—we think that the—we think we need to continue purchases until the—until reserves are at a level at which they will not go below $1½ trillion, roughly, during the course of the calendar year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we know that the TGA will move up and down there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So they’ll be much higher than that some of the time, but that’s kind of the number, and we think we’ll reach that sometime in the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s our estimate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we will—we’ll know it when we get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll know it because we’ll be able to be—to control the federal funds rate without use of—without active use, ongoing use of open market operations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, our intention of these—for these adjustments is just to raise the level of reserves and to allow us to conduct monetary policy in an efficient and effective manner.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s—that is our sole intention.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I pointed out on other occasions, more than once, the differences—the really specific differences between this and the large-scale asset purchase programs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been over that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of what affects markets, you know, I think many things affect markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very hard to say with any precision at any time what is affecting markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I can tell you is that you know what our intention is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is to return reserves to an ample level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect that to happen during the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And our plan as we do that is, as those purchases get to that level, we believe we can gradually reduce them, and we believe we can also gradually reduce repo as—as we reach an ample level, as we’re satisfying demand now more from underlying reserves from bill purchases rather than from repo.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, the last thing I’ll say is, we’re prepared to adjust the details of this plan as we’ve shown ourselves willing to do depending on conditions.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Jeanna Smialek from the New York Times.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I was hoping that you could talk a little bit about the labor market.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: We’ve recently seen wages moderating a little bit by some measures, maybe even declining a little bit by others.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: As you mentioned, at the lower end of the sort of talent pool, it seems like we are seeing those wages climb up a little bit, but it doesn’t seem to be consistent across the entire sort of average.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I was wondering if you’d talk a little bit about whether you guys are noticing any cracks, or whether you’re worried about that, or how you’re thinking about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market continues to—to perform well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market continues to be strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see strong job creation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see low unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very importantly, we see labor force participation continuing to move up, really, against expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you go back a few years, you will not find a lot of forecasts suggesting that we could have been at 63.2 percent overall labor force participation or the levels of employment to population that we’re seeing now, let alone the unemployment level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we’ve learned quite a lot of good things about the labor market, good things suggesting that there’s been more room to run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The performance of wages, I think, has to be seen in that context.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We saw—if you go back four or five years, the four or five major wage statistics that we track were running at around 2 percent, and now they’re running at around 3 percent, which is theoretically about where they might be at full employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would consist of inflation plus—plus productivity growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The—it’s a bit surprising that, with sustained levels of historically low unemployment, we haven’t seen wages moving up above that level as we have in other long expansions and other periods of low unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you asked, what can be explaining that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, one thing can be that the natural rate of unemployment is still lower than we think, that the labor market is not as tight as it would appear just from the 3½ percent number.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the other can be, I think, that—as I mentioned, the sort of supply-side shock or surprise that we’re receiving from higher labor force participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People are coming in to the labor market and providing more labor supply, and that is—that’s a great thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a very healthy thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re a country that has low labor force participation compared to essentially all of our advanced-economy peers, and it’s a very good, positive thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, it represents more labor supply, and it may be holding down wages.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Radio and Television.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: In terms of the framework review and a little bit on Chris’s question earlier, there is a general feeling now in the markets and among analysts that you’re basically setting us up for some form of inflation-target averaging where you let the inflation rate run above the 2 percent target for some time to make up for the time that it has spent below that.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Is that a fair or reasonable assessment of where you think you’re going to end up?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: What would you, Chairman Powell, think of that idea personally?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: And, as long as I’m asking, do you have any more details on when we can expect the results of the review?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll just say that we undertook the review because we felt, and I felt, that it was time to incorporate the realities of what we could call the “new normal” into our policy framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And some aspects of that new normal would include ongoing powerful global disinflationary trends, which have led to lower-than-target inflation many places in the world; secondly, a flat Phillips curve, by which I mean low levels of sensitivity of inflation to resource utilization—for example, low unemployment; and, thirdly, a much lower neutral real interest rate here and around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are challenging conditions for monetary policy to deliver on our statutory goals of maximum employment and stable prices, although I would say that, under our existing framework, we’ve been able to succeed or get close to succeeding it for most of the time lately to achieve those goals, although we do struggle, as other central banks do, with the inflation goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is about reviewing our strategy, tools, and communications to assure that they’re the best that we can do to achieve those goals in this environment on a sustained basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we continued our discussions at this meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m very, very pleased at the process so far.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s included the 14 Fed Listens events around the country, at which we’ve engaged with a full range of people and groups across American society.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was a very, very positive experience, and I think we learned a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve now had a series of—a number of FOMC meetings at which we’ve reviewed what we’ve learned and also dug deeply into strategy, tools, and communications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I expect that we will conclude the review and announce our conclusions around the middle of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, we are just at the point of coming together to put all that together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think I’m not the person who should be telling you my personal preferences right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m trying to—and we were trying to come together as a group around a set of answers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I feel very positive about—that we’re going to come up with some good results, and I’m just going to have to wait until we get to that point to announce them.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Donna Borak with CNN.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Going back to your outlook for global growth, we’ve seen some significant headwinds, as you mentioned earlier, with the easing—with the partial U.S.–China trade deal, but now that there’s some new concern following the outbreak of the coronavirus—that it might shake global growth.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: We’re already seeing reports from Ford and Toyota that they’re planning to shut down their assembly plants for an extra week.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Apple is rerouting their supply chains.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Starbucks is shutting down close to thousands of stores.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Are you worried at all about what the impact would be on the U.S. economy, and do you see that as a significant risk—excuse me—to the outlook at this point?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me talk about the coronavirus specifically, and then I’ll turn more to global growth more generally.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First, it’s a—it’s a very serious issue, and I want to start by acknowledging the significant and considerable human suffering that the virus is already causing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is likely to be some disruption to activity in China and possibly globally based on the spread of the virus to date and the travel restrictions and business closures that have already been imposed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the situation is really in its early stages, and it’s very uncertain about how far it will spread and what the macroeconomic effects will be in China and its immediate trading partners and neighbors and around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in light of that uncertainty, I’m not going to speculate about it at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will just tell you that, of course, we are very carefully monitoring the situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, as you suggested, our framework ultimately is, what are the potential ramifications for the U.S. economy and for the achievement of our dual mandate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More broadly, though, if I can talk about the global economy for a second—and if you look at the backdrop, you know, if you go back to 2017, that was the year of synchronized growth that lasted into the middle of 2018, and then you saw slowing in growth, which lasted right through the end of last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fourth-quarter growth globally was quite weak last year, and a number of factors played into that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It wasn’t any one factor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was trade policy uncertainty, absolutely, but also there was the decision by the Chinese authorities to try to rein in leverage and financial excesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was a turn—downturn in the global high-tech manufacturing cycle in global auto production.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There were some idiosyncratic strains in some countries like Argentina, Turkey.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then, later, in Hong Kong and Chile, you had social unrest.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, all of those things were playing into that cycle of weakening growth over the course of 2019 and the last half of ’18.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, now there are grounds for what I would call “cautious optimism” about the outlook now for the global economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many analysts are predicting a pickup in growth this year, although still to relatively modest growth rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would—people are pointing to, and we would point to, supportive financial conditions, the easing of trade tensions, the lower odds of a hard Brexit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The high-tech manufacturing industry does appear to be rebounding well in Asia, including in China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The latest indicators—manufacturing PMIs, for example—suggest that manufacturing may have bottomed out, that they’re still below 50 in many jurisdictions, but they have moved up off of their lows.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would—I would just say, none of this is assured.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, we saw the fourth quarter of last year came in quite weak—weaker than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are not at all assured of a global rebound, but there are signs and reasons to expect it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then comes the coronavirus, which, again, it’s too early to say what the effects will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’re, as I mentioned, monitoring it carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There will clearly be implications, at least in the near term, for Chinese output and, I would guess, for some of their close-in neighbors, and we’ll just have to see what the effect is globally.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: Brendan Greeley with the Financial Times.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: As recently as 2018, interest on excess reserves was at the top of the band, sort of dragging the fed funds rate up.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: Over the course of the adjustments since last year, it’s moved steadily down, closer to the bottom of the band.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: So, if you’re moving it back up, how high do you want to get it?

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: Are we looking to get interest on excess reserves at the top of the band again as the fed funds rate moves to the middle of the band?

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: And should we see movements in IOER as an indicator that we’re approaching “ample”?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So our stated goal is to keep IOER and the federal funds rate well within the range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well within the range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, clearly, you know—5 basis points from the bottom or from the top isn’t that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s why we moved back up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Last year we were—we saw some tightness as reserves were draining out of the system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We saw the—gradually moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, in hindsight, we know what was happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With ample reserves, we see—we see that it’s possible to bring the interest on reserves rate up to 10 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So now we’re—now we are well within the range, I would say.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: We are.

speaker: BRENDAN GREELEY
sentence: So you don’t think that, as the fed funds goes back up towards the center of the range, that IOER is going to end up at the top?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Don’t know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want it to be well within the range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ll continue to adjust it to the extent it’s appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, what we’re trying to do is deliver a federal funds rate that’s well within the range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: IOER is just a tool to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we—if we need to make changes to keep it well within the range, we’ll do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just means—I mean, the thing that matters for the economy is that we keep the federal funds rate—which is the rate that, of course, transmits into other money market rates, which ultimately transmit into all kinds of financial conditions—that’s what we care about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, ultimately, we will—we will use that tool to keep it well within the range.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Howard Schneider with Reuters.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Just to sort of close the loop on one thing, where do discussions stand on a standing repo facility?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Because what you’ve said so far sort of implies that there won’t be one or that it will be a limited one.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: So if you could just, you know, let us know where that discussion stands.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: And also— UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Can you turn mic over?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Turn the mic over.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Sorry about that.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Sorry about that.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Did you get the question?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Did you hear the question okay?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think—I’m not sure your colleagues did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: [Laughter] HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Where do the discussions stand on standing repo?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: [Aside] That was great.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the other thing is, on the, you know, on the standing repo facility and on the purchases—Treasury bill purchases, as you enter this new regime later in the second quarter or later in the year, will that be preannounced by amounts?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Will there be preset amounts like you’re doing now, or will that just be something that people will have to sort of intuit and figure out as you go along?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ll go in reverse order.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When we—when we make decisions about the steps we’re going to be taking in that adjustment process that I described at some length, we’ll be making them as early as we can and as transparently as we can—and specifically.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re not at that stage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s January, and we’re several months away from—from that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the standing repo facility, as I mentioned in, I guess, in my answer to an earlier question, there may well be a role for repo in this system even after we’re at an ample-reserves level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, we haven’t decided what that role is, we have not decided—we haven’t at all made a decision on a standing repo facility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve had a couple of discussions about it, as you know, back in, I guess, June and October.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there’s a range of views.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to return, I would say, fairly soon to this question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it was wise to wait, because we’re still getting a better sense of what that—what that world looks like.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s really going to be a question of, how useful will it be?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What will be the costs and benefits?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And my thinking is, we will return to that fairly soon, and I wouldn’t assume a decision one way or the other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, we haven’t made one, because we haven’t had to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think you—when you delay, you get more information by waiting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s good to wait.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t have any urgency in making that decision, because we’re still trying to find that sort of stable equilibrium where we’re in an ample-reserves regime.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Heather Long from the Washington Post.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: I’m wondering, do you think that there is a financial stability risk from climate change?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: You’ve spoken several times that you think severe weather events are happening more often and that the Fed is monitoring what that could physically do to a bank or a financial institution, but that’s sort of one institution.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Do you think there’s a systemwide risk that may—that could develop from climate change?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s an interesting question—the question being, is there a systemwide financial stability risk?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d say, over—over the longer term, it’s certainly possible, and I would say that sort of feeds into the way we’re thinking about climate change as an institution.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I’ve mentioned, climate change is an important issue, a very important issue, but it’s essentially assigned to many other agencies in the federal government and state governments for leadership on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, importantly, society’s overall response to climate change needs to be decided by elected officials and not by the Fed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of that said, if you look at our mandate, we’ve got a monetary policy mandate and, more immediately perhaps, a supervisory mandate where we’re supervising financial markets, utilities, and financial institutions, banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we haven’t—we share overall responsibility for financial stability with a number of agencies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that latter part—I think the public has every right to expect and will expect that we will assure that the financial system is resilient and robust against the risks from climate change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, I think that’s got to be right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are in the very early stages, as are other central banks, in understanding just what that means.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there’s quite a lot of work going on around the world at other central banks and at the Fed, too, to think that through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I do think it’s—in that sense, it has to be part of our role, and—but not the overall response of society to climate change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not us.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: And if I could follow up, can you clarify why the Fed hasn’t signed on to the Network for Greening the Financial System like 40 other central banks have?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve attended all of their meetings and taken part in them, and we’ve been looking at joining in one form or another and talking to them about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We probably will do that at some point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s—that’s an ongoing question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re very much attending those meetings and taking part in them.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Edward Lawrence from Fox Business Network.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So there was a signing of a ratified USMCA at the White House today.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Mid-February, the phase-one China deal gets—goes into effect.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Have you seen business investment pick up at all?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: If not, what will it take to get that business investment going as this uncertainty is—is being cleared up?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I’d start by saying that the fact that we’ve reached a phase-one deal with China and the fact that we’ve moved ahead closer to getting USM[C]A agreed—those are potentially positive things for the economy without question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And financial markets—the reaction of financial markets is very consistent with that perception.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A sustained reduction in uncertainty over time should improve business sentiment, investment, which would provide some additional support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s important, though, to bear in mind a couple of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First, trade policy uncertainty remains elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Businesses continue to identify it as an ongoing risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We still have two or even three active trade discussions that are going on in the public square right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it hasn’t gone away, and we’ve just come through a round of talking to our vast network of comments—sorry, contacts in the business world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, clearly, these are seen as positive developments going forward, but there’s a bit of a wait-and-see attitude—is this going to be sustained?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The agreements have to be implemented, too, and that’ll take quite some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I would say, we need to be a little bit patient about the effect on the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s also the global economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You could—you could well see manufacturing—as I mentioned, manufacturing PMIs have started to tick up consistently among both advanced economies and emerging market economies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do not see a decisive recovery, but it’s possible that this mix of positive developments and also accommodative financial conditions could spur further growth.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Hi, Mike Derby with Dow Jones.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Do you have any greater sense of what—what was going wrong with the repo market starting in September?

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: There seemed to be, you know—whether it was a one-off event, you know, too tight around tax payments and debt settlement, or whether there’s a more enduring issue going on with the market, more structural forces that are basically gumming up the repo sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As for those forces, so, as we indicated, we would undertake a, you know, serious review of that question and look at both our regulations and also supervisory practices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’d be prepared to adjust those in ways that might encourage liquidity to flow more easily in the system as long as it didn’t undermine safety and soundness.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’ve undertaken that, and we’ve done a ton of work, actually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t have anything to announce here today, but I feel good about the—what we’ve learned there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think—you mentioned other factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will be announcing our findings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to give you a time, but we’re—we’re well along in that assessment at this time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we also found out, though, that the level of reserves that we need in the system to conduct our operations without frequent resort to open market operations was higher than we had thought and was higher than others had thought, too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We learned that we can’t let reserves—we shouldn’t let reserves go below $1½ trillion—roughly, the level of early September—at any point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that means that reserves will move through in a range over the course of the year that will be substantially higher than $1½ [trillion], but they won’t ever go below.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So $1½ [trillion] is not a target level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is the bottom of a range in which reserves will be expected to move.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Hi, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: I just wanted to ask about how your balance sheet operations and repo—temporary repos—how they affect the system and who they’re helping.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Clearly, they’re mostly designed, as you said, to get—keep the fed funds rate in the range you’re looking for.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: But, certainly, the repo market is also used heavily by hedge funds and other Wall Street institutions.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And so, how would you explain to, sort of, Main Street why you’re doing all this for that market?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And how would you address criticism that it is helping mostly Wall Street, along with everything else?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, let me just stress that we have a very specific and important reason for caring about money market operations generally, and that just is that we are—our monetary policy decisions are transmitted through the financial markets—through the money markets into other financial markets and into broader financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we care that money markets are operating smoothly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they stopped operating smoothly, briefly, back in September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we acted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a one-time thing that we’re doing to adjust the level of reserves so that the money markets will be able to operate smoothly on an ongoing basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Repo markets are important, because that’s where Treasury securities—the purchase of Treasury securities, which is the way—you know, the federal—part of the way the federal government is funding its operations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s the way those are financed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So these are largely Treasury securities that have been purchased by dealers to—for distribution to—and buyers, to a substantial extent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what’s going on in the Treasury repo market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s just the financing for—for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, again, we don’t—that activity is a—is a market activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not looking to eliminate volatility or protect anybody from volatility at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we care about is that volatility in the repo market can affect the transmission of—of our policy decisions to federal funds rate, and that really is important for the public.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Chair Powell, is the Fed going to vote tomorrow on changes to the Volcker rule restrictions on banks investing in venture capital funds?

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: What can you tell us about what the Fed is considering?

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: And why make those changes?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we will be looking tomorrow and voting on a—a new part of—part of the existing Volcker rule, and that is the covered fund provisions of the rule.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be making a bunch of proposed revisions that we believe are faithful to both the letter and the spirit of the law.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to put those proposals out for public discussion, and we’re going to listen carefully, as we always do, to public comments on those proposals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, we believe that they will be—and you’ll see them tomorrow—will be public—you know, will be publicly—we have a Board meeting tomorrow to do that.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Now, is this just the venture capital funds, or are also you changing the rules for hedge funds and private equity funds?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s covered funds.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—so it’s that covered—so it’s not the proprietary trading part of Volcker.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s the covered funds part.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: And is there a chance that banks could take this and run and maybe even get involved in mortgage-backed securities again and risky investments?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ll—we think that what we’re doing is—is very consistent with safety and soundness and absolutely consistent with the letter and spirit of the Volcker rule.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be—we’ll be getting comments from people, and we’ll be looking into that question, among many others.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you, Chairman Powell.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I’d like to turn your attention back to China and the health of its financial sector in particular.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And I guess I’m basing my question on reading the transcripts from 2014 that came out earlier this month.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Just—in March of that year, there was concern about the Chinese economy, and one of your colleagues on the FOMC at that time asked the staff about how the Chinese economy would hurt—hit the U.S. economy.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And the staffer said that there was a—what they were worried about was that not only was the Chinese economy slowing down, but there was the financial sector.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And the quote was: “There’s a tremendous amount of dodgy loans in China.” Now, I was wondering if you could give us an update on these problems in the Chinese financial sector.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And how do you think it might impact the economy, particularly now that they’ve been hit by this unexpected shock?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, China has had a problem for some years, including from that period—2014 up until, I guess, ’17 or ’18, and I thought—which was essentially just a lot of debt for an emerging market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For an economy at the—at the stage of evolution of the Chinese economy, they had very high levels of debt—not sovereign debt the way we think of it, but more business debt—debt of state-owned enterprises and also just private businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And a couple of years ago the authorities decided to try to get that under control—to stop the growth and to control it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that—as I mentioned, that’s one of the reasons why Chinese growth slowed, and it’s one of the reasons why global growth slowed, because we felt that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’ve actually stuck to that even during this difficult period when they were experiencing, you know, strains from trade negotiations and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The authorities have stuck to that and have, again, continued to try to do that, so—to try to control the growth of debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s important that they do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think that—that there’s any imminent risk there, although you—as you point out, the coronavirus thing is a significant thing, which will—will have some effects on the Chinese economy, at least in the short term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Chinese economy is very important in the global economy now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we—when China’s economy slows down, we do feel that—not as much as countries, though, that are near China or that trade more actively with China, like some of the Western European countries.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We still have—you know, 85 percent of our economy is domestic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have a much smaller external sector, trade sector, than other economies just because of our physical location.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Hi.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Brian Cheung here, Yahoo Finance.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: So the combination of T-bill purchases and repo operations have been described colloquially as “liquidity.” I’m just wondering if you semantically agree with that description—then, secondly, what the impact of that has been on risk assets.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: I don’t know if that’s something that, you know, the Board or Reserve Banks are formally looking into or just looking at what the effect of it has been.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: How are you kind of thinking about that going forward?

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so, two questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, in terms of liquidity, I think what we’re doing is what I said: We’re trying to raise the level of reserves back up to a level so that banks can meet their reserve requirements, and that there’s enough reserves in the system that we don’t see reserve scarcity, and we don’t have to use repo operations to provide additional reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think, as I mentioned, we believe we can get to that state at the current pace sometime in the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of effects on risk assets, as I said earlier, it’s very hard to say what is affecting financial markets with any precision or confidence at a given time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not our intention to change the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These were designed to provide more reserves and, really, to do that in order to enable better transmission of our—of our rate decisions into the economy under our chosen framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s really the purpose of what we’re doing.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Hi.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Jean Yung with MNI.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: I wanted to ask about the framework review again.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Would a shift of focus to inflation over an average period—would that call for a different policy stance if you made that shift?

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: And whether or not we know the answer to that question, would the Fed consider changing the stance of monetary policy for that reason even if there was no change to the economic outlook?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, as you know, we’re comfortable with our current policy stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’s appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it’ll remain appropriate as long as data coming in are broadly in keeping with our outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over time—over time, though—let me take a step back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over time, an average inflation-targeting framework would be different than our current framework, in the sense that it wouldn’t be a—there would be some aspect of trying to make inflation average 2 percent over time, which means, if it runs below 2 percent for a time, it has to run above to bring the average up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is a different framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our current framework is one where we say—or we’d be equally concerned with deviations of inflation from target on either side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that isn’t—that doesn’t suggest an intention specifically to have those deviations be symmetric.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In other words, that would—consistent with that would be having all the deviations be on one side, which is what we’ve had, actually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think it is a change in framework, and over time it would lead to a different approach to policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I’m not trying to—I don’t want to comment on the current stance of policy, which we do think is appropriate.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Don Lee with the L.A. Times.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: I wanted to ask you about the stock market.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: By historical comparisons, as you know, valuations are considerably high.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: And I just wonder how much discussion and concern you and your colleagues have about that and what risks you see for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—we look at a very broad range of financial conditions where—there isn’t any one financial condition that we—that we look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when we look at financial conditions, what matters for the real economy is substantial changes in—or, material changes in financial conditions that are sustained over a period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If I can, maybe I’ll—maybe I’ll answer that in the context of our overall financial stability framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one way to look at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at—when we look at financial stability, we look at—really, we’ve got four pillars to that, the first of which is leverage in the financial system that is at a comfortable level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our banks, particularly our large banks, have high levels of capital.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second is leverage in the nonfinancial sector, and that divides into households and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Households’ debt to GDP is—has been coming down since the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s at low—low levels compared to what it was before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So not every household—but, in the aggregate, household debt is in a good place, a very good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business debt has been moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been calling that out for more than a year—substantially more than a year, and it’s something we’re focused on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve taken appropriate measures and are monitoring carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we think it’s not something that would threaten financial stability, but more be an amplifier.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other one is asset purchases, getting to your—sorry, asset prices, getting to your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do see asset valuations as being somewhat elevated—I do—somewhat elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at risk spreads, they’re narrow.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at P/Es, they’re high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the way to think about—a good way—one way to think about equity prices, though, is, what’s the premium you’re getting paid to own equities rather than risk-free debt?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s also at fairly low levels, but not extremely low levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So valuations are high, but not at extremes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The final factor is funding risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Are big financial institutions and other players in the financial system funded with stable funding, or is there a lot of run risk?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the answer is, very stable funding, for the most part.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at, overall—what you see, in my view, is, vulnerabilities to the financial—to financial stability are moderate overall.

speaker: KATY O’DONNELL
sentence: Hi.

speaker: KATY O’DONNELL
sentence: Katy O’Donnell, Politico.

speaker: KATY O’DONNELL
sentence: I wanted to know, do you support Governor Brainard’s vision for the Community Reinvestment Act reform?

speaker: KATY O’DONNELL
sentence: And is this something that we could see the Fed formally propose at some point?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me say that I think this is a good time to do—to update CRA, really, in a way that is a win–win both for the intended beneficiaries—low- and moderate-income communities—and also for banks that would like to have more certainty about—about what does and doesn’t qualify and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The law can both be more effective and more efficient is—it comes down to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think this is a good way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also just a good time to take on board the way the delivery of banking services has changed through technology and demographic change as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We worked very hard to try to get on the same page with the other two agencies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that an interagency final rule together would be the best outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re sorry we haven’t been able to get there, and we still hold out some hope that we will be able to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We spent a lot of time on research and analysis and looking at meaningful reform.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You saw Governor Brainard’s recent speech presenting some of the thinking and the analysis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we haven’t made any decisions about what we’re going to do, about whether we’ll propose—I mean, our focus has been entirely on trying to get to agreement with the OCC, really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we haven’t made any decisions about what we’re going to do going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of, you know—Governor Brainard led our oversight committee over these activities for many years, and I asked her to take the lead on CRA modernization, which is a high priority for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I was comfortable with her speech, and I’m comfortable with the work we’ve done and with the Fed’s position on this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I said, we haven’t chosen to bring a proposal forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t decided what to do, whether—going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not going to comment on the other proposal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just not appropriate to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not about us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not about our views.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s about the views of the interested parties.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: Hannah Lang with American Banker.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: Thank you for being here today.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: I wanted to ask about Vice Chair Quarles’s recent speech on bank supervision in which he laid out some suggestions for making changes to the supervisory regime.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: I wanted to ask, do you agree with his approach?

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: And are there any plans to codify some of these suggestions later in the year?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I do agree that—the principles that he articulated of firm and fair supervision and effective transparency in communications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also think it’s a good thing that we would have brighter lines to define our LISCC supervisory portfolio, which we haven’t really had to date.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Remember that when a firm moves from one portfolio to another, that doesn’t mean that its level of scrutiny or supervision will change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and I also thought that, you know, the—he’s raising some very interesting questions about, if you—in the first part of the speech, where he’s talking about regulation and supervision and, you know, how to—how to balance the desire for transparency and due process in everything the government does with the needs of confidential supervision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a very challenging question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s one that could use further thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And as far as the specific, you know, proposals, there’s—you know, they’re interesting, you know, and need further development and will need lots of comment and that sort of thing.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Here we go.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Sorry, I had it [the microphone] upside down.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: That’s not too good.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Mark Hamrick with Bankrate.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: I wanted to ask you a question about the—one of the unintended consequences over the years-long low interest rate environment, and that is that savers haven’t gotten as much return as would have otherwise been the case.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: What would you say to those individuals who’ve seen the Fed again cutting rates, eroding their ability to get a higher return on their savings?

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: And how much would you take their plight into consideration?

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: How much can you sympathize with them?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—we are assigned a job by Congress, and that is to use our tools to pursue maximum employment and stable prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what—that’s our focus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, monetary policy is a blunt instrument, but it’s a powerful one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think if you look—look at the time since the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was—in the week [wake] of fairly modest growth, it was a powerful recovery in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And part of that just is the effect of lower interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, if—so many, many people benefit from low interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, you don’t hear—when you talk to the low- and moderate-income communities, one thing you don’t hear is, “You ought to raise rates.” That’s not what you hear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You hear quite the opposite, which is, you know, “Please do whatever you can to keep this expansion going.” I absolutely sympathize with people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you’re living on just the interest in a bank or on fixed-income generally, then that’s a challenging thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, if you own a home, home values—the housing market has recovered, other financial assets have recovered, so—but, yes, for some people who are limited to those sources plus whatever other help they get, it can be challenging.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we have to do what’s best for the—for the overall society and the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—those are our orders from Congress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
